Name: Sanjivini Society for Mental Health
Major_Activities1: Sanjivini is Delhi’s premier non-profit organization that has, since 1976, tirelessly addressed the emotional and mental health needs of society through counselling and rehabilitation of persons afflicted with schizophrenia. Our work is primarily carried out at two main units - the Counselling or Crisis Intervention Unit and the Rehabilitation Centre. At these centres, primary interventions as well as community-based and preventive initiatives are carried out. Below is a brief write up about our various programmes: Crisis Intervention: This Unit provides free and confidential psycho-social counselling for a wide spectrum of emotional distress and mental health problems, ranging from self esteem issues, inter-personal problems, depression, suicide, substance abuse and severe mental disorders. Our trained volunteer counsellors carry out this counselling. Rehabilitation Centre: This pioneering programme, which works towards the rehabilitation of persons suffering from chronic schizophrenia, has become a module that is being replicated by many other institutions. It is a full day therapeutic facility, which uses therapy at the group, individual and family levels. Referral Service: Through extensive networking with other organizations, we have built up a huge referral service. Equipped with this, we help our clients to get legal, medical or other specialized help, as required by them. Community Outreach Programme: Over the years, the sustained efforts of our ongoing Community Outreach initiatives have been directed towards the goal of destigmatizing counselling by raising the awareness of the community about different aspects of emotional and mental health and the help available. Basic Counselling Skills Course: This annually conducted workshop equips helpers in the community such as teachers, doctors and counselors with skills not only to make them better helper but also helps them to build more awareness of self which further leads to better relationship. In recognition of our contribution to society, Sanjivini has been honoured with the Sanskriti Award for 1982 and the Delhi Government award for valuable services rendered in 1998.

Name: Ladakh Institute of Prevention
Major_Activities1: Brief report on the activities of Ladakh institute of prevention (LIP) Health of the high altitude population of Ladakh and those coming to work in this region need special care and attention. Protection is required from the additional hypoxic conditions resulting from environmental pollution, Occupational related diseases, life style related diseases due to acculturization and high altitude related diseases. LIP over the years have carried out detailed epidemiological studies on these subjects and applied interventions to safeguard the population’s health and environment. LIP’s contribution towards environmental health: Through its action on smoking and health it has been able to reduce prevalence of smoking in adult male from 42 % in 1988 to 8% in 2010. This intervention has reduced incidence of acute coronary artery disease and lung cancer. Through our clinical, epidemiological, radiological, environmental and histo-pathological study, we identified mixed dust pneumoconiosis (Silicosis and coal worker’s type of pneumoconiosis) in the Indus belt population of Ladakh (Thorax 1991;46;341-343) and domestic pollution and respiratory illness in the Himalayan population (International Journal of epidemiology 1991;vol20;No3;749-757). The intervention practiced following it has improved the respiratory health of the population. LIP’s contribution in screening of the population in life style related diseases (Non-communicable diseases and cancer) During the last thirty years, Leh town have been colonized by rural people representing most of the villages of Ladakh. These population are now adopting a western model of life style threatening an impending disease of the new millennium. LIP did an extensive study (comprehensive health camp with service provision and health awareness campaign) in all the subdivisions of Ladakh on the prevalence of Non-communicable diseases from 2007-2011. The results on Prevalence of hypertension and diabetes have been published in BMJ open (2015;5:e007026) and (BMJ open;2016;6:e009728). Based on these works, LIP has distributed booklet and CD (in local language) on living “Healthy life style”. LIP’s works on screening of HBsAg (hepatitis B) in over 5000 subjects throughout the district has enlightened the population in getting the hepatitis B (HBsAg) negative subjects to receive full course of vaccine. Those with carriers of hepatitis B are being followed up and those needing anti-viral treatment are being supported by LIP. This activity will certainly reduce cancer of the liver. Through its medical and health awareness interventions the prevalence of stomach cancer has been reduced from 25 per one lakh population in 1997 to 8-10 per one lakh at present. Deficiency diseases in rural Ladakh. For the last five years, Lip’s health camps have focused on deficiency disease like Iron deficiency anemia, Vitamin D insufficiency, micro and macronutrient status in rural population of Ladakh. It has used validated questionnaires and hematological and biochemical assays (Hb, PBF; serum ferritin, Vitamin B12, folic acid, TSH) to determine the nutritional status particularly in Zanskar subdivision. Service provision and health education done simultaneously is proving effective in ameliorating these problems. Mother and child health. LIP is currently trying to establish “mother and child health care through a mother and child health handbook system” wherein the health of the mother from the first day of antenatal check-up to 9 months post pregnancy and the child from birth till 6 year will be documented in the hand book. We have so far documented 3000 mother and child under this system. High altitude adaptation. LIP is currently studying prevalence of chronic mountain sickness (CMS) in populations living at higher altitude (≥ 3800 meters). This study will help not only to understand the factors leading to loss of adaptation (CMS) but also hypoxia related diseases like Dementia, cancers, lung and heart diseases. Previous work on adaptation and maladaptation have been published in PLoS one (June 2008 vol 3 issue6/e2342.)

Name: DADI HAMGIO CHARITABLE SOCIETY

To maintain the highest possible standard of humanitarian service by running welfare institute like orphanage/ Orphan school/ old age homes/Vocational Institute/ Training centers/ health center/ welfare of woman/ widow/ Welfare of children/ woman adult Education/ Discourage of Child and Force marriage. To assist and undertake preventive and control measures in disaster prone zones and crisis management in disaster stricken localities. To promote eco-tourism. To encourage rainwater rainwater harvesting and promote use of non- conventional means of energy in remote areas especially solar. To established functional linkages with other reputed NGOs functioning at state, Region,Nation, And International Level. There shall not be any profit motive while carrying out the activities and achieving the objects of the society. the surplus fund/ assist, if shall be utilized only in furtherance of the object of the society. Promote entrepreneurship in both rural and urban areas. Working handloom and handicraft activities and rural areas. To cooperate, collaborate with center/state and other agencies to undertake development programmes in Rural and Urban Areas. To conduct and also to assist in organising training and study courses, conferences, seminar, workshops etc. on rural development and allied subjects. To work towards better health in rural and urban areas, create awareness on AIDS/HIV and to address other similar issue in the broader interest of people. Name: ActionAid Association
Major_Activities1: ActionAid’s Achievements: Change in lives of Children: 1. 30,000 children enrolled into schools, 40% of them being girls. 2. 1706 cases of malnutrition among children addressed. 3. 1467 children rescued from child labour and reconnected to schools. 4. 7176 children from marginalised background received scholarship for higher studies 5. Around 1500 schools continuously monitored for basic amnesties and quality of education. 6. Around 350 Anganwadi centres are effectively functioning now. Change in lives of women and girls: 1. 11,000 girls were trained on sexual health rights 2. 9,000 women were provided skills training 3. 700 women survivors of violence received support from various resource centres linked to ActionAid. 4. Country’s first One-Stop Crisis Centre has been set up by MP government in collaboration with ActionAid. In Uttar Pradesh, a similar initiative is now underway and is expected to open in 11 districts. 5. We facilitated land titles to 50,100 persons, of which 12,000 are women. Change in the people’s lives vis a- vis Land, livelihood and agriculture: 1. 4457 Men and more than 3000 women now practising sustainable forms of agriculture in the areas we work in. 2. 2176 single women provided with homestead land titles in a joint initiative by District Authorities and ActionAid in Ganjam district, Odisha. 3. Around 58000 informal sector labourers now have access to social security schemes 4. Indigenous seeds are now stored in 200 villages promoting the practice of conserving seeds. Change in lives of youth community leaders: 1. Around 19,000 youths from socially excluded communities trained in ActionAid’s leadership schools on various aspects of the constitution, law and principles of social justice. 2. 5531 PRI members trained, 1080 of them are women. 3. 250 community watch groups formed to monitor public services provided by government. 4. Successful in advocating for appointment of 132 dalit women cooks in schools in the states of MP, Bihar, Rajasthan, Telegana and Uttar Pradesh.

Name: FORUM FOR CHILD RIGHTS
Major_Activities1: Name of Organization: Forum for Child Rights, Vijayawada, Year of Foundation: 1997 Legal Status: 383/1997 of Registration of Societies Act 1860, Vision of the Organization: To strive towards the creation of a child-friendly society where all the young under difficult situations are ensured of their rights – to survival, protection, development and participation – as enshrined in United Nations’ Convention on the Rights of the Child. Mission of the Organization: To make Krishna district as a child friendly district. Objectives: Every child, in and around Vijayawada, in need and care protection, is rescued/attended on an emergency basis and rendered support/rehabilitated. Convergence between governmental & the Civil Society (non-governmental organizations/academic organizations/ bilateral agencies/ corporate sector in protecting, advocating/monitoring the rights of children. Origin and Historical Development of the Centre / Project: Forum for Child Rights (FCR) is founded in 1997 with the initiative of the then Mayor of the City, late Shri. T. Venkateswara Rao. The FCR is a collaborative non-governmental organization consisting of various organizations, corporate agencies and individuals working for the welfare and development of the children in Need of Care and Protection in the city of Vijayawada and district at large. Since its inception the FCR has been advocating for the children in distress viz., street children, working children, begging children etc. FCR makes a special focus on the street children as they are more vulnerable to abuse and violence. FCR received CHILDLINE, 1098 (CHILDLINE is a national helpline service for the children who are in distress-a toll free call centre) funded by CHILDLINE India Foundation (CIF), Mumbai. Since, its inception 2000 CHILDINE Vijayawada rescued more than 40,000 vulnerable children and received more than 2 lakh calls from different corners of the district. The call centre functions 24 hours and it is located in T.V. Bhavan, Hanuman Pet of Vijayawada city. 5. WHAT IS CHILDLINE CHILDLINE is a national 24-hour free phone emergency and outreach service for children in need of care and protection. It responds to the needs of children and links them to long-term services. Some CHILDLINE key concepts are outlined below: National: CHILDLINE is a project of the Ministry of Women and Child Development, Govt of India. Currently CHILDLINE is functional in every district as per JJ Act, 2006. 24-hours: CHILDLINE is accessible at all times. Free: Accessible to any child, irrespective of economic status. Phone: A child or concerned adult, who finds a child in distress, can call 1098 when she / he have the need to speak to someone. Emergency: A crisis period in the child’s life during which intervention is required. The period lasts from the time of the call to such time that withdrawing assistance would put the child back into crisis. Services: CHILDLINE provides emergency assistance and then refers the child to other organizations for long-term rehabilitation. The services range from direct intervention such as medical assistance (hospitalization or out-patient), protecting children from abuse, supportive (legal, shelter, repatriation) to psychological (counselling) and providing information on other services for children in the city. Children in need of care and protection: Up to the age of 18 years and in extreme emergencies up to 25 years, children who are denied their rights especially street children, child labor, children who have been abused, child victims of the flesh trade, differently-able children, children affected by HIV / AIDS, children affected by conflicts and disasters, child political refugees, children whose families are in crisis. Linking children: CHILDLINE believes in emphasizing that the welfare of the child is a community responsibility that needs to be shared by all concerned adults and systems. Children / concerned adults call CHILDLINE for assistance. 6. VISION & MISSION The vision of CHILDLINE is to protect the rights of children in need of care and protection CHILDLINE aims at responding to the emergency needs of every child in need of care and protection throughout the country and ensure that there is an integrated effort between government, non-government organizations, academic organizations, bilateral agencies, corporate sector and the community in protecting the rights of children. 7. OBJECTIVES OF CHILDLINE i) To reach out to every child in need of care and protection by responding to emergencies on 1098 ii) To provide a platform of networking amongst organizations and to provide linkages to support systems that facilitate the rehabilitation of children in need of care and protection iii) To work together with the Allied Systems (Police, Health Care, Juvenile Justice, Transport, Legal, education, Communication, Media, Political and the Community) to create child friendly systems. iv) To advocate for services for children that are inaccessible, nonexistent or inadequate v) To create a family of NGOs and Government organizations working within the framework of national vision and policy for children. vi) The CHILDLINE would organize CHILDLINE ADVISORY BOARD every 3 months under G.O. Ms. No. 4 (Women Development & Child Welfare & Disabled Welfare (JJ) Department, Government of A.P.), dated 29.1.2002. The Chairman of the CAB is the District Collector and the members are all the allied systems. Achievements: So far in 15 years service CHILDLINE, Vijayawada Run by Forum for Child Rights in Krishna District dealt with 35624 cases & sum of them life saving also. Name: Grace Society
Major_Activities1: Grace Society NGO Achievemnet Grace Society is a Church based Organization set up by the Mizoram Baptist Women Fellowship (MBKHP), to address the various social problems existing in the society. The organization mainly deals with the increasing problems of HIV/AIDS & Drug/Substance abuse in the community, in the field of Prevention, Intervention, Care and Support and Rehabilitation. It also deals with various women and children issues and addresses other vulnerable areas of the society. The organization has been working in Targeted Intervention programme since 2000, beginning with intervention among Commercial Sex Workers, followed by Core Composite of FSW & IDU in 2008, and with MSM and Spouses of IDU adding to the intervention since 2010. Mission Statement: 1) To create a better, healthier and harmonious society by reducing HIV/AIDS and Drug/Substance abuse in the society. 2) Economic empowerment of PLWHA and drugs victims, by providing rehabilitation through skill training and Income Generating Programme. 3) Social and economic upliftment of destitute women. 4) Promoting and facilitating behaviour change among those practicing high-risk behaviour and people living with HIV/AIDS. Vision/Goal: To create a better, harmonious, healthier society and improved economic condition by reducing HIV/AIDS and addiction in the community. Objectives: Increase awareness on HIV/AIDS and addiction among general population as well as high risk/marginalized communities, intervention to promote behavior change and harm reduction among high risk group, providing care and support to the affected, detoxification/de-addiction and rehabilitation through skill building, capacity building to enhance service delivery. 1. Targeted Intervention among FSW, IDU, MSM, & Spouses of IDU – Sponsored by MSACS, the programme includes peer education and outreach, focus group discussion, awareness, community events, STI clinic & general healthcare, abscess management, counseling, condom promotion, needle syringe exchange programme, referral to ICTC, ART, TB/DOTS centre, crisis response and management, empowerment of community, advocacy. 2. Integrated Program on drugs & HIV/AIDS – This mostly focus on aftercare program such as psycho-social support for recovering addicts through self help group meetings and support for income generation activities, educational support, support for skill development training to recovering addicts, care & support to PLWHA such as sponsorship for ART/Hospice referral, nutritional support to children of PLWHA, advocacy among church leaders, community leaders, school teachers & raising awareness among students, training among volunteers on sex and sexuality. This project is in partnership with TearAustralia. 3. Rehabilitation Center (Chhawmdawlna In) - This centre is set up by the Mizoram Baptist Women Fellowship in its own initiative the same time DIC was set up. Today the Rehab Centre can accommodate 30 boys and 20 girls at a time. It offers services like detoxification, Counseling, Meditation, Healthcare, Work therapy (including vegetable/flower gardening, Pig rearing, Dairy farming, Candle making etc), Physical Activity (Volleyball, badminton, table tennis) Rehabilitation through Skills training (including Electronics repairing, Bamboo craft, Carpentry, Tailoring and Flower making), Library, non-formal education to school going inmates.These programs besides TI are somewhat filling in the gaps that are not covered under TI. Each project complements and supplements each other. Having both DIC and Rehab is advantageous for target population in terms of referrals (as DIC clients are being referred to the Rehab for detox/deaddiction and rehabilitation while inmates released from Rehab are followed up from DIC). 4. Mental Health Program : One of the new project taken up by the NGO since 1st April , 2016 under National Health Mission in collaboration with National Mental Health Program.The Program mainly ensure the availability and accessibility of minimum mental health care for all in the foreseeable future particularly to the most vulnerable and underprivileged section of the population to encourage application of mental health knowledge in general health care and in social development and to promote community participation in mental health service development by organizing many awareness campaign & free clinic to reduce suicidal tendency in various department,school,colleges,church and sectors. 5. Home Visit, Nutritional & PLWH Support : Besides TI project, NGO give important to the client that almost every year the staff/NGO conducted house to house visit program trying to identify all hidden client and aware of each clients health condition so that follow –up program can be easily done as per client condition. Also, NGO continues significant ministry by giving nutritional support to positive child and rendering service and care to the positive client whose condition are in below average normal life to elevate their Condition.This support for nutritional and PLWHA mostly comes from charity and donation.

Name: Jan Mitram Kalyan Samiti
Major_Activities1: Achievements • Over 8000 direct beneficiaries of various project spread among 3 district of Northern Chhattisgarh. • Formation and nurturing over 850 Women self help groups, cumulative saving INR 12.6 million. Credit Mobilized for SHGs from Nationalized Banks up to INR 18.67 Millions. • Promotion of NTFP, Medicinal Plants and horticulture species for additional source of income among tribes. Establishment of marketing and Value addition Facility for related products. • Spearheaded Promotion of Lac cultivation spread among 5200 beneficiaries, quadrupled Production in 3 years. • Development of entrepreneurship and marketable skills among youth, over 350 trained youth successfully running small business . • Water conservation awareness drive and watershed development program converged with livelihood promotion in two blocks of Raigarh district. • Network of 836 Community health worker (MITANINS) in two blocks of Raigarh District to addresses Mother and child care issues . • Village level awareness rising campaigns at regular intervals for children’s nutrition requirement, sanitation, immunization and family planning issues. • Designated monitor For Projects sanctioned to agencies under National Forestation and Eco-development Board (NAEB-MoEF-GOI and Chhattisgarh state Medicinal Plants Board. • Technical Support Institution (TSI) to District planning Committee (DPCs) in two districts of Chhattisgarh, for decentralized annual planning of various development schemes. • Empanelled as Agency for Micro planning under rural development and forest departments of Chhattisgarh Government. Prepared micro plans for over 366 villages, Panchyats, and Joint forest management committees (JFMCs). Divisions : • Jan mitram is providing variety of services to community Wide array of our services need specific division of labor among teams. Therefore , We have three distinct divisions, which shoulder different type of responsibilities. • A. Project Implementation Division: This division which looks after long-term projects given by external agencies, especially those who jump to more than one financial year. Accounts are kept separate so that various funding agencies can access any time, how their funds are utilized. Staff of PID, except seniors, also varies according to the number and need of projects. • B. Social Services Division: This division’s mandate is to serve to poor, advocate for weaker sections, human rights and various awareness activities. A permanent Crisis Management Cell has been constituted in SSD, including volunteers and workers. This cell run relief operations during natural disasters i.e. flood, fire, accidents etc. SSD receives its fund from member’s contribution and donations. • C. Survey, Monitoring and Evaluation Division: This is small but efficient group of experts, who shoulders short time assignments of organization. Its scope of work is Survey, data collection, Micro-planning, project planning, Monitoring & Evaluation of projects, Documentation and report preparation for Organization and Other agencies.

Name: Indian Council for Child Welfare Tamil Nadu
Major_Activities1: ICCW,TN started in 1953 works for child survival, development, protection and participation with a holistic approach of strengthening families and communities. There is branch in every District of Tamil Nadu with the Collector as President and a Committee of Official and non Official Members. Programmes include Prevention of Female Infanticide and empowerement of women and girls in Madurai District. Achievement- From 200 infanticides recorded in 1988 to nil in 2001. Programmes for prevention and rehabilitation of Child Labour in match and beedi industry in Virudhunagar and Vellore Districts. Achievement- Stoppage of bonded labour system in Beedi industry. Now Phase II of projects focusing on vocational training through educational sponsorship(Vellore) and Community College ( Srivilliputhur). Programmes for Child Protection: Crisis Intervention Centre for prevention, rescue, rehabilitation and after care of child abuse and neglect Childline 1098 a 24 hour toll free number for children in distress at Chennai (South)and Cuddalore. Project for identification and rehabilitation of Child Beggars at Chennai Training of Multidisciplinary professionals to respond to child abuse cases Training of Watchdog Committees in Panchayats for prevention of trafficking of children Established a Network of NGOs in 32 Districts of Tamil Nadu for Child Protection. Workshops for Stakeholders on Child Protection in all districts of Tamil Nadu with Government appropriate authorities and NGOs Workshops for children on Child Rights and Protection in all Districts and State Level. Residential Institutions for children at Chennai, Thiruvallur and Thanjavur Districts for destitute and hearing impaired children. Community Based services: Creches for children of working women – 147 (2009) in the State. Financial Sponsorship Support to families for care and education of children to prevent child labour or Institutionalisation. Counselling and Guidance for Special Needs children. ICCW,TN provides psychological and financial assistance for physically and mentally challenged children and their families. Services include awareness, identification of disabilities, referral and counselling services. Training:- Training of Child Care Workers is a core activity of ICCW,TN. Training of Balasevikas, Anganwadi workers, etc has been done since 1962. The Training of Supervisors for ICDS Programme through out Tamil Nadu is done by ICCWTN since 1985. Short Term Training Workshops for Teachers, Creche Workers and others are conducted on various child related issues – Preschool Education, Nutrition, Child Protection etc. Community Colleges at Chennai and Srivilliputhur have been started to offer Job oriented Training such as Computer Hardware, Child care, Fashion Designing, etc to disadvantaged Youth. Adoption Services – ICCWTN acts as a consultant to the Courts in Tamil Nadu who forward applications for Adoption of a child, whether In country or Inter country, for scrutiny and comments by the Council. The Information, Documentation and Research Centre of the Council undertakes various studies on child centred issues which include An analysis of the State Budget and Expenditure on Children 1998 -2004, A study of children placed in Indian Adoption, etc. It also documents and publishes reference books such as “Child and Law in India” a compilation of all laws concerning children, a Directory of Child Welfare Institutions in Tamil Nadu.

Name: calcuttabahari
Major_Activities1: Calcutta Bahari is a well known leading theatre & cultural, social development organization. Through out this period group has produced 26 fulllenghth drama and have performed 360 shows in different stages of Bengal as well as India. Group generly perform 25 shows annully. That includes several one act plays & street shows.We also working among rural urban areas, Landless peasants, marginal farmers, share coppers, distitute womens, poor children, labour-class areas to create awarness among social economic development through differnt NGOs of Govt. of India and Govt. of West Bengal. SEMINAR & SYMPOSIUM : It has been organized in renowed auditorium, schools, colleges, market, rural area & other important location of various social & cultural issues in the field of Comunal harmony, crisis of modern theatre, folk & rural and tribal art, RESEARCH WORK : A research work on lyrical theatre is going on directed by Sri Anupam Roy, also doing research work on tribal & traditional rural folk arts fordevelopment, preservation, mordanise in the purose of folk theatre. AWARDS : Bahari has received RANGAKAL award 2005 for the drama RAMRAMA RANGALILA which is running for last14 years.Also received best production of the Year 2008 given by ANUBHAB NATYA SANGSTHA for drama ARSHI. IN HOUSE WORKSHOP : It has been organizing since last 8 years by renowned & reputed theatre personalities and senior member & Guru. Also we had conducted workshop & production participated and performed by the school students, street child and slum children. REMARKABLE PRODUCTION & INVITIONS: RARAMA RANGALILA, MEHEJAN, ASHMAPTA ADHYAY, ANCHAL,DUI KADA etc. Kolkata Dooradarshan telecated documentary performance of lyrical theatre along with an interview of the director. Full length drama MEHERJAAN telecasted by Kolkata Dooradarshan and HATHAT DEKHA of Tagore. Audio drama ANCHAL boradcated from AIR Kolkata KA.Natya Mela of Govt. of West Bengal, Rabindra Jayanti, Vidyasagar Meal, Purulia Zella Utsab, Srijan Utsab - tribal & Folk. Participated in World leteracy Day, International Womens Festival in Kolkata, Ganga Jamuna Internatiional Festuval in Kolkata. Different Autumns Festivals in NEW DELHI, MOMBAI & HYDRABAD. Group has already achieved a few musical insturments, theatrical equipments and essential material for office work. The group has geared up talented full time theatre performers and Workers. Also proviedes them a little remuneratiion. GURU PRANAM AND FELICITATION : In different occaddion Bahari organized felicitation programme in their differnt festivalsto the emiment personalities of the society.

Name: The Calcutta Samaritans
Major_Activities1: Inception: The Calcutta Samaritans was born in 1971. Rev. Vijayan Pavamani, our founder, and his wife Premila Pavamani, our current Director, began their work to befriend the lonely in crisis, from the veranda of a small cottage that was their home. The Calcutta Samaritans is a registered, secular, autonomous and voluntary organisation. We have now been able to befriend a much wider range of persons with special needs. From the suicidal to the substance abuser through treatment and rehabilitation; from those at risk of STD’s and AIDS to a larger group NGOs being trained in drug awareness and de-addiction; The Calcutta Samaritans has honed in to the marginalized for which the organization campaigns and advocates. The organization has grown beyond all expectation with over 150 Samaritans working day and night to ease pain, loneliness and suffering. Rev. Pavamani believed that those who came to us were not ‘cases’, or numbers, but persons in need, who needed to be cared for, and “the person more important than their problems”. By personal example in his lifetime, Rev. Vijayan Pavamani focused on the individual; proving that it is not the work itself, but the manner in which one does the work that is important. This is the work ethic that we have adopted. We strive to, quite simply, be there for those who come to us. The vision: The Calcutta Samaritans’ vision is a community that affirms the dignity and self-worth of the individual and ensures their holistic empowerment. The mission: We are a movement of people working to improve the quality of life of individuals in society: By listening, befriending and counseling through education, healthcare and advocacy, rehabilitation, self-scheme projects and job-skills development for the upliftment of the community. The following are the projects/departments of the organization: • Awareness Assistance and Counselling Centre for substance abuse • De-addiction centre supported by MSJE at Kolkata and Jamshedpur • Long term rehabilitation and aftercare centre for substance abusers • Targeted intervention for IDUs and FSWs supported SACS • Regional Resource and Training Centre supported by MSJE • Campaign and advocacy supported by Actionaid • Vocational rehabilitation & job skills training centre • Work place prevention programmes in Kolkata and at Jamshedpur • Pathological laboratory

Name: Noble Cause Foundation
Major_Activities1: Noble Cause Foundation was conceptualized after rendering years of services as non registered voluntary agency. The NGO in its current avatar and even before incorporation as Society have touched multitude of issues on poverty alleviation and basic human rights. Our approach has been need based and towards a long lasting solution. In the past we had opportunities to participate in national exhibitions as partner and reaped in all benefits to showcase the talents possessed by artisans and handicraft workers. Introducing unknown talents to national level platforms and scope for improvisation gives us the sense of accomplishments which we wish to replicate as far as possible. We are successfully running library cum resource centres in remote villages of Darbhanga, Madhubani and Bettiah district of Bihar. Over 5000 children and teachers have benefited from this initiative and its our desire to add more teeth and scale the model elsewhere. Awareness and sensitization programs on myriad of issues like environment, deforestation, health ailments , road safety, natural and manmade disasters, panchayati raj institutions, rights and entitlements of people specifically the vulnerable sections like women, children and people suffering on stratification blues owing to their caste, creed and religion. These awareness drives have yielded results on many fronts and of late we have been receiving requests from schools and educational institutions to carry out the awareness drive on issues concerning their pupil. We have noticed a remarkable change in the attitude of the people as far as their health seeking is concerned. The realization that diseases and sufferings are not curse of the nature and has nothing to do with past karma is something our organization has professed right from inception. In this regard Family Counselling Centers and Counselors have been roped in Bihar and Delhi to pledge a effective intervention. Death of resources notwithstanding we have supporting primary school children of SC community in Bettiah in their educational pursuits and attainment of holistic development. The project has benefited over 1000 children in last three years. We have successfully arranged excursion tours, provided toys and stationery, gift items and have conducted workshops on art and craft, diya making, decorative items etc. In the past we have successfully organized seminar on Conflict Reporting in India in collaboration with Jamia University. Notable journalists and academics participated in the seminar to discuss the burning issue of resolving conflicts all over the world and how should media report in such crisis situation. It’s the common man who suffers the most if conflict erupts. The event was eye opener for us also as it showed us the true picture of contrasting life before and after the manmade disasters. We have successfully organized cultural events and fests to promote culture of Mithilanchal and spread the need to preserve traditions and dialects. The contributions of great sons of Mithila have been highlighted by our talks, speeches and panel discussions in schools and meetings. The society is affiliated to Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan, Ministry of Sports and Youth Affairs, Govt. of India

Name: Society for Integrated Human Development
Major_Activities1: By the patronization of Central Social Welfare Board New Delhi the organization has set up a Family Counseling Centre at Angul wef: 7th Jan,2004.The main thrust behind the programme is to strengthen the social fabric by preventing families from breaking-up and promoting harmony within the family through counseling by the counselors. It is providing preventive, curative and rehabilitative services to the women who are victims of atrocities. The centre aims at providing distressed women with services like crisis intervention, investigation in dowry death cases, counseling in the cases of marital/family mal-adjustment, reconciliation in cases of separation and out -of-court settlement in the marital cases and referral services like short stay, legal aid and police assistance etc. The organization by the financial support of State Social Welfare Board, Odisha, and Bhubaneswar has been implementing 2 Nos. Creche Centres under the Rajiv Gandhi National Creche Scheme Programme for the children of working mothers since 1st Feb, 2006 at Angarabandha and Santarapur of Angul to promote a healthy all round development of children of working/ailing mothers particularly those employed in the unorganized sector and belonging to the BPL category. The crèche offers parental care, nutritional food intakes, motivation for coverage of immunizations, recreational facilities and pre-school education to 60 children within the age group of 0-6 years of the working and ailing mothers of the locality.

Major_Activities1: The spectrum of our activities: • Shelter Homes at Ma-Dham, Vrindavan • Kashmir Intervention, Raahat Ghar-Kashmir. • Vocational Training Programs at Sawai Madhopur Rajasthan and Najafgarh, Delhi. • Group Marriage Ceremony for under-privileged and marginalized. • Mahilla Panchayat and Mohalla Meetings • Gender Resource Centre. • Legal Literacy Camps. • Self help groups. • Family Counseling Centre in Delhi, Sawai Madhopur and Vrindavan. • Working Women’s hostel • Campaign for Police Accountability. • Peace Initiatives The Five programmatic achievements of our organizations are as follows: I. Under the relm if Auxiliary Nurses training course we have got 90% placements including placements in private and government hospitals. They are successfully earning upto Rs. 20,000/- II. Intergrated home for the widows, which is a first of its kind. Under one roof the widows get the benefits of doctor facility, physiotherapy, green environment, food and shelter, leading towards a meaningful & healthy life. III. 1300 women belonging to the lower income strata in Delhi are organized into self help groups. The money is deposited in banks and achor during personal crisis as well as to start the new business. IV. Under the Empowerment of Widows Coalition-UN women project we have successfully created and trained 5 widow HRD’s (Human Rights Defenders). They have further created 300 defenders in the five villages adopted by the Guild around Vrindavan. This has help to create a lot of awareness towards self help groups and problem solving. V. We have successfully settled the lives of 50,041 girls including widow’s remarriage, inter-caste, inter community, differently abled couples towards a change in the society since 44 years of its existence.

Name: RANG MADHYAM Natya Sanstha
Major_Activities1: RANG MADHYAM Natya Sanstha is an association of theatre ,painter,writer & artists under the young and demonic peoples . Its goal is to bring cultural awakening among the people of India. It is the cultural wing of the several performing art group in ideological platform with the initial members of the groups are young artists. The group was formed in 2003 with great motto, in the background of the wake of the people. Our Association always try to the group presents it is idea and objective of representing the crisis of the time through the medium of theatre and to help people understand their rights and duties. Our movement hit not only theatres, but also cinema and music in Indian languages. RANG MADHYAM has been active and practicing theatre in this Capital district of Madhya Pradesh. In 2003, when the Bharat Bhavan Rang Mandal was closed, some young people decided to create the high level quality performance of Drama with ideologically. In this way should be established an association and organizing the several street play & Proscenium Show. In that way during the years of establishment we have been reorganized and it spread its activities, started imparting training and updating artists by means of organizing theatre workshops every year for youth as well as for children time to time. Since 2003, theatre stalwarts like Prabhat Ganguli, Gul Vardhan, Javed Zeidi, Jayant Deshmukh, have conducted workshops and trained our artists. Besides doing theatre own city, RANG MADHYAM Natya Sanstha started participating in various festivals to showcase their productions in different cities like Bhilai, Jabalpur, Raipur, Ashok Nagar, Itarasi, Indore, among the few.

Name: SRI SAI MAHILA SANGAM
Major_Activities1: ACHIEVEMENTS AND LESSONS LEARNT FROM LAST YEAR WORK SRI SAI MAHILA SANGAM is a community based organization which consists of an executive body, general body and staff who are working completely with service motto. Sri Sai MahilaSangam was established in 1999, Registration of Society 29th July 1999, Registration No. 5149/1999, AP (Telangana areas) Public Society, Registration Act 1350 Fasli (Act I of 1350 F). Sri Sai MahilaSangam community Organization is working with Children, youth, women, community and health programmes. FSW TARGETED INTERVENTION PROJECT: As a part of FSW targeted intervention project SSMS our origination working on health awareness programs has concentrating on promotion of awareness on HIV/AIDS and educating the key population on condom as well as STI problems. As the HIV/AIDS epidemic began to proliferate in the country India, the organization felt the urgent need to address the issue by way of generating awareness among high risk groups as well general population. Since Tuberculosis is one of the most opportunistic disease for the people suffering with HIV/AIDS as well the prevalence of Tuberculosis is considerably high among the developing countries, the issue of Tuberculosis is also addressed by way of creating awareness in our adopted area of operation. With gender inequality, health status and herein addition to the awareness programs; In this year one-one, one-group, focus group and counseling sessions were organized especially for sex workers and migraines labour in the Nacharam, Mallapur, Charlapalli, industrial areas and also in Kapra, Old Malkajgiri, Tarnaka, AdikmetHabsiguda,Balajinager, Barath Nager, Bollaram, Chennapuram, Indira Nager, Defiance colony, Dental college, Gowtham Nager, Lothukunta, Macha Bollaram, Nethaji Nager, Old Alwal, S.P. Nager, Safilguda, Vayupuri, Venkatapuram, and Yapral. By Commercial sex workers. Sexual transmission accounting or more than 75% of spread of HIV in the area. Activities of the Intervention The organization is implementing the Programme through core Components: 1. Behavior Change Communication 2. STD Care Services 3. Condom Promotion & Distribution Programme 4. Enabling Environment. 5. Referrals & Linkages 6. Community Mobilization Committees Formation in the Programme: 1. Project Advisory Committee The Committee is Comprising of 9 members is representing 1/3 from programme Administration, 1/3 from Outreach Team and 1/3 from Community People. The basic aims and objective this committee to organize the review meetings for quarterly once and review the programme plans vs Achievements for the three months period and identify the gaps forms the review in each component and takes the resolutions for recommendations to take up on priority basis. 2. Crisis Management and Advocacy Committee The Committee is formed to response the community issues regarding any violence, discrimination, police harassment, gundas harassment etc. This committee to advocate the problem for smooth full solution and sensitize the issues at anywhere in project services on priority basis. The committee comprises of 7 members team, 2 from the project team, 1 from the Outreach team, 3 from the community and 1 from the out sourcing lawyer, the team is very active in the issues of community issues. They are organizing the legal literacy camps in DIC and Hotspot level for creating the awareness on District Legal Services Authority for free legal Advices, Domestic Violence Act-2005, ITPA Act etc. CBO Formation: In this Year, we have complete the CBO registration, to startup the some of the activities for supporting to programme. And to form a Hotspot Level Leaders; to sensitization to the key population, prior response to crisis management, developing health seeking behavior among key population and negotiating with pimps and madams for consistence use of condom by the key population.  SSMS has strong networking linkages with Govt. Depts. / NGOs / training and capacity building to various stake holders  Availability of trained, qualified, experienced, committed and skilled Staff  Strong involvement of community in the project activities  Mallapur,Nachram,Dammaiguda and Balajinagerareas most of in migration  Lot of improvement of HRGs attendance, participation various activities  With the help of CARE & TSACS conducted CBO elections represented 36 hotspot area HRGs  Regular review of Project Officer, TSU and Internal reviews with SSMS  On 20th day of February, 2013, after a comprehensive mobilization the previous day by the CARE team in association with the project staff, CBG leaders. Elections conducted at SSMS office (DIC). 30 Hot spot leaders have took part in this activity and the whole process went on well in a smooth, conducive and democratic manner.  Candle Light programme.  Blood donation Day programme.  DSRC Referrals are increased.  Community active participation on Blood Donation Camp  International Women’s Day programme  Women Empowerment Day programme  Child Labour eradication programme with out of school children in our field areas

Name: THE INSTITUTE OF SOCIAL RESEARCH AND APPLIED ANTHROPOLOGY
Major_Activities1: Facets of Activities of the Institute of Social Research and Applied Anthropology(ISRAA) The Institute of Social Research & Applied Anthropology had, since its inception in 1955 had been engaged in activities related to social welfare, research studies, action research, cultural promotion of indigenous population etc. in different parts of West Bengal and neighbouring states. Many great personalities like Prof. Nirmal Kumar Bose, Prof. Probodh Kumar Bhowmick, Dr. J.K. Bose, Prof. L.P. Vidyarthi, etc., to name a few, had been the principal source of inspiration and actions research in this organization. Till date it had conducted many academic research as well as action research with actual implementation concerning poverty alleviation, social awareness, capacity building and other livelihood improvement programmes. It has with its experts and staff, significant experience of evaluation and assessment related project execution in and urban development fronts. A. Action & Applied Research: 1. Since inception 8 Nos. of Research Projects on various issues related to Tribal Development livelihood programme etc. in general and Lodha, a primitive tribe West Bengal. was carried out by the staff and scholars of the institute. The projects were duly sponsored by Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Govt. of India. 2. During 2006-08 we executed a project entitled “Empowerment of Tribal Women through Batik Print: Training cum Production” sponsored by Dept. of Science & Technology, Govt. of India. New Delhi. As a part of the project we trained 90 tribal women belongs to various tribal communities in and around Bidisha. In view of their show interest we formed 9 SHG,s. Out of 9 Nos. of SHGs except 2 others are functioning. 3. One Research Fellow namely Dr. Monali Goswami who attached with our institute and carrying out her research work entitled “Nutritional Status among the mother & children of Bhumij of Orissa” funded by Indian Council of Social Science Research, New Delhi. 4. In the field of education we are running 3 Ashrama Hostels - 2 for Boys and 1 for Girls exclusively for Lodha children. Ashrama Hostel which is residential where free food and lodging facilities being provided to the inmates duly financed by BCW Dept, Govt. of West Bengal. It is to be mentioned here the first Ashrama Hostel in the state of west Bengal . 5. Our existing land and pond are being utilized for commercial purpose in view of generating our own resources for sustainability on one hand and the other it is being used for demonstration purposes by inviting the experts time to time from IIT, KGP as well as concerned Agriculture Dept, Govt. of West Bengal to transfer the need based technology to the tribal and non tribal people living side by side in and around Bidisha. 6. We organized Aloe-Vera training for the youth farmer of the locality. The training was imparted by the faculty of Agriculture and Food Engineering Dept. IIT. KGP. 7. We have installed Bio- gas unit and vermi- compost plant to impart training facilities to the local tribal youth to provide the means of sustainable livelihood to the local people in view of entrepreneur development of Tribal Folk. 8. Very recently the District Sericulture Board established a Tasar-cum-Mulberi cultivation, training-cum- Production Unit at our Institute for employment and income generation in Paschim Medinipur. B. Organising National & International Level Seminar Since inception our institute very successfully organized 36 Nos. National seminars and 3 NOs. of International Seminars duly sponsored by the agency like Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Indian Council of Social Science Science Research, New Delhi, Anthropological Survey of India, Cultural Research Institute, West Bengal etc. The 4th International Seminar will be held during December, 4th to 5th 2016. C. Publication We are publishing very regularly a journal namely “Man & Life” 2 issues Jan- June & July – Dec. We feel proud by expressing, since last 37 years this journal covering all the branches of social science being published regularly. Altogether total 20 Nos. of books are being published by our institute under the heading “Sparks from Bidisha” D. Revival of Tribal Art & Culture With the aim of revival of tribal art & culture our Institute organizes every year “ Navanna” Utsav where different tribal communities are to perform their various cultural events which aregradually decaying due to impact of modern mass- media and telecommunication causing the identity crisis among the indigenous communities. Our Institute is putting its endeavor to provide a platform where the missing tribal cultural traits are being staged and this happens to be the eye opener before younger generation of various communities as a source of motivations and challenges. E. Eco-museum is located at our institute. There is enough scope for the expansion and popularization of ecologically sensitive activities in village life in terms of promotions and rejections. F. Throughout the year, the students of Rural Development, Anthropology, Bengali, History, Sociology, Folklore etc. of different colleges and universities of West Bengal and out side the state are organizing their field camps and workshops at our institute.
